author: Simon Mullock
title: Manchester City chief delivers damning assessment of Pep Guardiola's disappointing first season as manager
text:
Sport Manchester City chief delivers damning assessment of Pep Guardiola's disappointing first season as manager The Blues were expecting to challenge for the title and Champions League right away under the Spaniard but instead face a scrap just to finish in the top four Share Manchester City's top brass (inset) expected more from Guardiola in his debut year   Thank you for subscribing!   
Pep Guardiola has so far failed to deliver on the sky-high ­expectations of Manchester City 's owner Sheikh Mansour. 
Guardiola’s admission last week that winning the title in his debut season is now beyond the Blues has not gone down well in Abu Dhabi, as chairman Khaldoon Al Mubarak launched Project Pep with a promise that they would mount a challenge for the Premier League and Champions League this season. 
The Catalan now faces a desperate fight to deliver the minimum requirement laid out to all City managers since the Sheikh’s 2008 takeover — a top-four finish. 
But Sunday Mirror Sport understands the club’s ­paymasters are prepared to spend whatever it takes to ensure boss Guardiola is a success. Watch — Pep Guardiola's press conference after the heavy defeat at Everton: Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Share this video Watch Next 
They are ready to back their manager – and underperforming director of football Txiki Begiristain – with a massive transfer war-chest ahead of next season. 
But the bottom line is that when Khaldoon delivered a damning assessment of Manuel Pellegrini’s final year in charge, he also revealed that Sheikh Mansour expected Guardiola to ­immediately replicate the success he masterminded at both Barcelona and Bayern Munich. 
Khaldoon said: “I have to say I have a lot of expectations. Maybe I shouldn’t be saying that right now, but I owe it to the fans. 
“Sheikh Mansour is approaching this year — as every other year, but ­particularly this year — with a lot of expectations. And I am working very hard to make sure that together with Pep – with our management team, the rest of our organisation – we’re going to do everything possible to make sure this team is well set for a hugely successful season.” 
Those words came back to haunt Khaldoon after ­Guardiola admitted City’s title hopes were over after the 4-0 h­umiliation at Everton last week. Sheikh Mansour ditched Pellegrini because fourth wasn't good enough (Photo: AFP/Getty) 
His reign began with a brilliant 10-match winning streak, but the realisation that the squad he inherited is past its sell-by date has long dawned on the 46-year-old former Barcelona and Bayern boss. 
And while there is an acceptance inside the Etihad’s corridors of power that Guardiola must be given time to impose his philosophy on the club, there is a huge sense of frustration that City still rely on 30-somethings such as Vincent Kompany, Yaya Toure, David Silva, Pablo Zabaleta and Gael Clichy. 
That is despite Begiristain ­sanctioning around £511million in new signings since arriving at the club in the autumn of 2012. 
City failed with an attempt to lure Guardiola to Manchester earlier that year and the club realised the best way to recruit the manager of their dreams would be to employ the two executives who played key roles at Barca when he was there. 
Ferran Soriano ­became chief ­executive in September 2012 and a month later was joined by Begiristain, a close friend of Guardiola. Begiristain has spent over half a billion pounds on signings in four years (Photo: Getty) 
One of their first tasks was to sack manager Roberto Mancini at the end of that season – after the Italian had finished second in the Premier League and reached the FA Cup final a year after delivering the title. 
Begiristain has wasted millions in the transfer market. 
Of the 28 players he has bought, only Kevin de Bruyne and Fernandinho have significantly improved the team. 
While Begiristain has also recouped just over £140m in player sales, the sorry state of his ­recruitment process was ­illustrated when he sent big-money signings Eliaquim Mangala, Samir Nasri and Wilfried Bony out on loan last summer — as well as England’s No.1 keeper Joe Hart. 
That scattergun transfer policy is now threatening to derail Guardiola’s first season. City quartet Mangala, Nasri, Hart and Bony are all out on loan (Photo: Getty/JMP/REX/Shutters​tock/MEN) 
We revealed in May that Pellegrini would have been sacked by City if he hadn’t already agreed to step aside after finishing 15 points behind surprise champions Leicester. 
The Blues did win the League Cup and reached the semi-finals of the Champions League for the first time in club history, but they needed a 1-1 draw at Swansea on the final day to pip neighbours Manchester United to fourth place on goal difference. 
Khaldoon explained Pellegrini’s ­performance wasn’t good enough. 
He said: “All of us came with high expectations for this season, and I cannot hide the disappointment of myself, obviously Sheikh Mansour, I know the fans of the club, and I’m sure the entire team. 
“Our objective is to win the Premier League every year and to go as far as we can in the Champions League and try to win the Champions League. These two are equally important and neither compromises the other or is at the cost of the other.” poll loading Will Manchester City win the Premier League under Pep Guardiola? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
